codeExamples.title: Basic Line Plot
codeExamples.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Create data
x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
y = np.sin(x)

# Create figure and plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(x, y, 'b-', linewidth=2, label='sin(x)')
plt.xlabel('X axis')
plt.ylabel('Y axis')
plt.title('Sine Wave')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()
codeExamples.explanation: This creates a simple sine wave plot with labels, title, legend, and grid.

codeExamples.title: Multiple Subplots
codeExamples.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(12, 10))

# Line plot
axes[0, 0].plot([1, 2, 3, 4], [1, 4, 2, 3])
axes[0, 0].set_title('Line Plot')

# Bar chart
axes[0, 1].bar(['A', 'B', 'C'], [3, 7, 5], color='green')
axes[0, 1].set_title('Bar Chart')

# Scatter plot
axes[1, 0].scatter(np.random.rand(50), np.random.rand(50))
axes[1, 0].set_title('Scatter Plot')

# Histogram
axes[1, 1].hist(np.random.randn(1000), bins=30, color='purple')
axes[1, 1].set_title('Histogram')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
codeExamples.explanation: Creates a 2x2 grid of different plot types using subplots.

codeExamples.title: Customized Plot with Styles
codeExamples.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Use a built-in style
plt.style.use('seaborn-v0_8-darkgrid')

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))

# Multiple lines with custom styling
x = np.linspace(0, 10, 50)
ax.plot(x, np.sin(x), 'o-', color='#FF6B6B', markersize=4, label='sin(x)')
ax.plot(x, np.cos(x), 's--', color='#4ECDC4', markersize=4, label='cos(x)')

ax.set_xlabel('X Values', fontsize=12)
ax.set_ylabel('Y Values', fontsize=12)
ax.set_title('Trigonometric Functions', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
ax.legend(loc='upper right', framealpha=0.9)

plt.savefig('trig_functions.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
plt.show()
codeExamples.explanation: Demonstrates custom styling, markers, colors, and saving high-quality figures.

codeExamples.title: Distribution Plots
codeExamples.code:
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Set theme
sns.set_theme(style='whitegrid')

# Generate sample data
data = np.random.normal(0, 1, 1000)

fig, axes = plt.subplots(1, 3, figsize=(15, 4))

# Histogram with KDE
sns.histplot(data, kde=True, ax=axes[0], color='steelblue')
axes[0].set_title('Histogram with KDE')

# Box plot
sns.boxplot(data=data, ax=axes[1], color='lightcoral')
axes[1].set_title('Box Plot')

# Violin plot
sns.violinplot(data=data, ax=axes[2], color='lightgreen')
axes[2].set_title('Violin Plot')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
codeExamples.explanation: Shows three different ways to visualize the distribution of data.

codeExamples.title: Correlation Heatmap
codeExamples.code:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Create sample DataFrame
np.random.seed(42)
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'Feature_A': np.random.randn(100),
    'Feature_B': np.random.randn(100),
    'Feature_C': np.random.randn(100),
    'Feature_D': np.random.randn(100)
})
df['Feature_E'] = df['Feature_A'] * 0.5 + np.random.randn(100) * 0.5

# Calculate correlation matrix
corr_matrix = df.corr()

# Create heatmap
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 8))
sns.heatmap(corr_matrix, annot=True, cmap='coolwarm', center=0,
            square=True, linewidths=0.5, fmt='.2f')
plt.title('Feature Correlation Heatmap')
plt.show()
codeExamples.explanation: Creates a correlation heatmap to visualize relationships between features - essential for ML feature analysis.

codeExamples.title: Categorical Data Visualization
codeExamples.code:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load sample dataset
tips = sns.load_dataset('tips')

fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(12, 10))

# Bar plot with hue
sns.barplot(data=tips, x='day', y='total_bill', hue='sex', ax=axes[0, 0])
axes[0, 0].set_title('Average Bill by Day and Gender')

# Count plot
sns.countplot(data=tips, x='day', hue='time', ax=axes[0, 1])
axes[0, 1].set_title('Visits by Day and Time')

# Box plot with categories
sns.boxplot(data=tips, x='day', y='tip', hue='smoker', ax=axes[1, 0])
axes[1, 0].set_title('Tip Distribution by Day and Smoker Status')

# Swarm plot
sns.swarmplot(data=tips, x='day', y='total_bill', hue='sex', ax=axes[1, 1])
axes[1, 1].set_title('Bill Distribution (Individual Points)')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
codeExamples.explanation: Demonstrates various ways to visualize categorical data with Seaborn.

codeExamples.title: Interactive Scatter Plot
codeExamples.code:
import plotly.express as px
import pandas as pd

# Load sample data
df = px.data.gapminder()
df_2007 = df[df['year'] == 2007]

# Create interactive scatter plot
fig = px.scatter(
    df_2007,
    x='gdpPercap',
    y='lifeExp',
    size='pop',
    color='continent',
    hover_name='country',
    log_x=True,
    size_max=60,
    title='GDP vs Life Expectancy (2007)'
)

fig.update_layout(
    xaxis_title='GDP per Capita (log scale)',
    yaxis_title='Life Expectancy (years)'
)

fig.show()
codeExamples.explanation: Creates a bubble chart where you can hover over points to see country details.

codeExamples.title: Animated Chart
codeExamples.code:
import plotly.express as px

# Load gapminder data
df = px.data.gapminder()

# Create animated scatter plot
fig = px.scatter(

    y='lifeExp',

    range_y=[25, 90],

)

fig.show()

codeExamples.title: 3D Surface Plot
codeExamples.code:
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import numpy as np

# Create data for 3D surface
x = np.linspace(-5, 5, 50)
y = np.linspace(-5, 5, 50)
X, Y = np.meshgrid(x, y)
Z = np.sin(np.sqrt(X**2 + Y**2))

# Create 3D surface
fig = go.Figure(data=[go.Surface(z=Z, x=X, y=Y, colorscale='Viridis')])

fig.update_layout(
    title='3D Surface Plot',
    scene=dict(
        xaxis_title='X',
        yaxis_title='Y',
        zaxis_title='Z'
    ),
    width=800,
    height=600
)

fig.show()
codeExamples.explanation: Creates a 3D surface plot that can be rotated and zoomed interactively.

codeExamples.title: Basic Streamlit App
codeExamples.code:
import streamlit as st
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

# Page config
st.set_page_config(page_title='My Data App', layout='wide')

# Title and description
st.title('ðŸ“Š Data Explorer')
st.markdown('Explore your data interactively!')

# Sidebar for inputs
st.sidebar.header('Settings')
num_rows = st.sidebar.slider('Number of rows', 10, 100, 50)
show_stats = st.sidebar.checkbox('Show statistics', value=True)

# Generate sample data
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'Date': pd.date_range('2024-01-01', periods=num_rows),
    'Sales': np.random.randint(100, 1000, num_rows),
    'Region': np.random.choice(['North', 'South', 'East', 'West'], num_rows)
})

# Display data
st.subheader('Data Preview')
st.dataframe(df)

# Conditional statistics
if show_stats:
    st.subheader('Statistics')
    st.write(df.describe())

# Chart
st.subheader('Sales Trend')
st.line_chart(df.set_index('Date')['Sales'])
codeExamples.explanation: A complete Streamlit app with sidebar controls, data display, and charts. Run with: streamlit run app.py

codeExamples.title: ML Model Prediction App
codeExamples.code:
import streamlit as st
import numpy as np
from sklearn.datasets import load_iris
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier

# Load model (in practice, load a trained model)
@st.cache_resource
def load_model():
    iris = load_iris()
    model = RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=100)
    model.fit(iris.data, iris.target)
    return model, iris.target_names

model, target_names = load_model()

st.title('ðŸŒ¸ Iris Flower Classifier')
st.write('Enter flower measurements to predict the species')

# Input widgets
col1, col2 = st.columns(2)
with col1:
    sepal_length = st.slider('Sepal Length (cm)', 4.0, 8.0, 5.0)
    sepal_width = st.slider('Sepal Width (cm)', 2.0, 4.5, 3.0)
with col2:
    petal_length = st.slider('Petal Length (cm)', 1.0, 7.0, 4.0)
    petal_width = st.slider('Petal Width (cm)', 0.1, 2.5, 1.0)

# Prediction
if st.button('Predict Species'):
    features = np.array([[sepal_length, sepal_width, petal_length, petal_width]])
    prediction = model.predict(features)
    proba = model.predict_proba(features)
    
    st.success(f'Predicted Species: **{target_names[prediction[0]]}**')
    st.write('Confidence:')
    for name, prob in zip(target_names, proba[0]):
        st.progress(prob, text=f'{name}: {prob:.1%}')
codeExamples.explanation: An interactive ML model demo with sliders for input and probability display.

codeExamples.title: File Upload and Analysis
codeExamples.code:
import streamlit as st
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px

st.title('ðŸ“ CSV Analyzer')

# File upload
uploaded_file = st.file_uploader('Upload a CSV file', type='csv')

if uploaded_file is not None:
    df = pd.read_csv(uploaded_file)
    
    st.subheader('Data Preview')
    st.dataframe(df.head())
    
    st.subheader('Data Shape')
    st.write(f'Rows: {df.shape[0]}, Columns: {df.shape[1]}')
    
    # Column selector for visualization
    numeric_cols = df.select_dtypes(include=['number']).columns.tolist()
    
    if len(numeric_cols) >= 2:
        st.subheader('Create Visualization')
        col1, col2 = st.columns(2)
        with col1:
            x_col = st.selectbox('X-axis', numeric_cols)
        with col2:
            y_col = st.selectbox('Y-axis', numeric_cols, index=1)
        
        fig = px.scatter(df, x=x_col, y=y_col, title=f'{x_col} vs {y_col}')
        st.plotly_chart(fig, use_container_width=True)
else:
    st.info('Please upload a CSV file to get started')
codeExamples.explanation: A file upload app that analyzes and visualizes uploaded CSV data.

codeExamples.title: Complete Dashboard with Streamlit
codeExamples.code:
import streamlit as st
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px
import plotly.graph_objects as go

st.set_page_config(page_title='Sales Dashboard', layout='wide')

# Generate sample data
@st.cache_data
def load_data():
    import numpy as np
    dates = pd.date_range('2024-01-01', periods=365)
    df = pd.DataFrame({
        'Date': dates,
        'Sales': np.random.randint(1000, 10000, 365) + np.sin(np.arange(365) * 2 * np.pi / 365) * 2000,
        'Region': np.random.choice(['North', 'South', 'East', 'West'], 365),
        'Product': np.random.choice(['A', 'B', 'C'], 365)
    })
    return df

df = load_data()

# Header
st.title('ðŸ“ˆ Sales Dashboard')
st.markdown('---')

# Filters
col1, col2, col3 = st.columns(3)
with col1:
    selected_region = st.multiselect('Region', df['Region'].unique(), default=df['Region'].unique())
with col2:
    selected_product = st.multiselect('Product', df['Product'].unique(), default=df['Product'].unique())
with col3:
    date_range = st.date_input('Date Range', value=(df['Date'].min(), df['Date'].max()))

# Filter data
filtered_df = df[
    (df['Region'].isin(selected_region)) &
    (df['Product'].isin(selected_product)) &
    (df['Date'] >= pd.Timestamp(date_range[0])) &
    (df['Date'] <= pd.Timestamp(date_range[1]))
]

# KPI Cards
st.markdown('### Key Metrics')
kpi1, kpi2, kpi3, kpi4 = st.columns(4)
kpi1.metric('Total Sales', f'${filtered_df["Sales"].sum():,.0f}')
kpi2.metric('Average Sale', f'${filtered_df["Sales"].mean():,.0f}')
kpi3.metric('Total Transactions', f'{len(filtered_df):,}')
kpi4.metric('Best Day', f'${filtered_df["Sales"].max():,.0f}')

# Charts
st.markdown('---')
chart1, chart2 = st.columns(2)

with chart1:
    st.subheader('Sales Trend')
    daily_sales = filtered_df.groupby('Date')['Sales'].sum().reset_index()
    fig = px.line(daily_sales, x='Date', y='Sales')
    st.plotly_chart(fig, use_container_width=True)

with chart2:
    st.subheader('Sales by Region')
    region_sales = filtered_df.groupby('Region')['Sales'].sum().reset_index()
    fig = px.pie(region_sales, values='Sales', names='Region', hole=0.4)
    st.plotly_chart(fig, use_container_width=True)
codeExamples.explanation: A complete interactive dashboard with filters, KPI cards, and multiple charts.
